clusters.title: I found something strange on my back – and eventually I just couldn’t ignore it | Adrian Chiles
clusters.neutral_headline: I found something strange on my back – and eventually I just couldn’t ignore it | Adrian Chiles

items.title: I found something strange on my back – and eventually I just couldn’t ignore it | Adrian Chiles
items.standfirst: When I first discovered this vaguely troubling symptom, I embarked upon my tried-and-tested routine for dealing with such things: 1. Pretend it’s not there. 2. Acknowledge it is. 3. Convince myself it’s growingThe NHS is a funny fish. It often kind of almost works brilliantly. Almost but frustratingly, not quite.I had this thing on the back of my shoulder which, being where it was, I couldn’t quite see. I could feel it though. A moley, warty thing. I’ll spare you a fuller description. Continue reading...

clusters.title: End-of-life care needs a fundamental review, not just more funding | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: End-of-life care needs a fundamental review, not just more funding | Letters

items.title: End-of-life care needs a fundamental review, not just more funding | Letters
items.standfirst: Prof Sam H Ahmedzai and Dr Greg Mewett respond to an editorial about the crisis in funding in England’s adult hospice sectorYour editorial (29 October) highlights the urgent need for better funding for end-of-life care. As a physician and academic who has worked in this area for 40 years, I would like to raise three underlying issues.First, it implies that hospices are the only model for delivering good end-of-life care. It is arguable that in Britain we have overrelied on the charitable sector. We now have NHS-funded hospital palliative care teams who can provide excellent care when patients are coming to the end of life but still needing specialist treatments – which very often hospices cannot or will not offer. Continue reading...
items.content: Prof Sam H Ahmedzai and Dr Greg Mewett respond to an editorial about the crisis in funding in England’s adult hospice sectorYour editorial (29 October) highlights the urgent need for better funding for end-of-life care. As a physician and academic who has worked in this area for 40 years, I would like to raise three underlying issues.First, it implies that hospices are the only model for delivering good end-of-life care. It is arguable that in Britain we have overrelied on the charitable sector. We now have NHS-funded hospital palliative care teams who can provide excellent care when patients are coming to the end of life but still needing specialist treatments – which very often hospices cannot or will not offer. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the need for a review of end-of-life care.
It suggests hospices are not the only model for care.
NHS-funded palliative care teams can provide excellent care.
Hospices may not offer all specialist treatments.
The article highlights underlying issues in end-of-life care.

clusters.title: Belén review – gripping true story of woman unjustly accused of illegal abortion
clusters.neutral_headline: Belén review – gripping true story of woman unjustly accused of illegal abortion

items.title: Belén review – gripping true story of woman unjustly accused of illegal abortion
items.standfirst: In Argentina a lawyer fights to free a working-class woman jailed after the miscarriage of her baby in this heartfelt retelling Belén is a pseudonym; in 2014, a 25-year-old woman arrived at a hospital in Argentina with severe abdominal pain that turned out to be a miscarriage. She had no idea she was 22 weeks pregnant, but doctors suspected she had had an abortion, then illegal in Argentina, and called the police. Belén was charged with aggravated homicide and sentenced to eight years in prison. When her case was taken up by feminist lawyer Soledad Deza it sparked protests, thousands taking to the streets in green scarves. This heartfelt drama tells the story, mostly from the perspective of lawyer Deza (played by the film’s director Dolores Fonzi).It begins in the hospital. The doctor in charge barely bothers to look up at Belén from his clipboard – she is a poor working-class woman and this will determine her fate. After a foetus is found in the hospital toilet, police arrive, handcuffing Belén to her bed. They do not carry out DNA tests on the foetus, so there is no physical evidence – a fact not raised by the blood-boilingly lazy defence at her trial. The real-life Belén has always chosen to remain anonymous, which might explain why her character takes a back seat here, though Camila Plaate’s sensitive supporting performance gives us a glimpse into Belén’s growing political awareness. Continue reading...
items.content: In Argentina a lawyer fights to free a working-class woman jailed after the miscarriage of her baby in this heartfelt retelling Belén is a pseudonym; in 2014, a 25-year-old woman arrived at a hospital in Argentina with severe abdominal pain that turned out to be a miscarriage. She had no idea she was 22 weeks pregnant, but doctors suspected she had had an abortion, then illegal in Argentina, and called the police. Belén was charged with aggravated homicide and sentenced to eight years in prison. When her case was taken up by feminist lawyer Soledad Deza it sparked protests, thousands taking to the streets in green scarves. This heartfelt drama tells the story, mostly from the perspective of lawyer Deza (played by the film’s director Dolores Fonzi).It begins in the hospital. The doctor in charge barely bothers to look up at Belén from his clipboard – she is a poor working-class woman and this will determine her fate. After a foetus is found in the hospital toilet, police arrive, handcuffing Belén to her bed. They do not carry out DNA tests on the foetus, so there is no physical evidence – a fact not raised by the blood-boilingly lazy defence at her trial. The real-life Belén has always chosen to remain anonymous, which might explain why her character takes a back seat here, though Camila Plaate’s sensitive supporting performance gives us a glimpse into Belén’s growing political awareness. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The film tells the story of a woman accused of illegal abortion.
The woman, Belén, was jailed after a miscarriage in Argentina.
The lawyer, Soledad Deza, fought to free Belén.
The film is based on a true story.
The film highlights the injustice of the situation.

items.title: Fixing Britain’s worklessness crisis will cost employers £6bn a year, report says
items.standfirst: The Keep Britain Working review, created to tackle the rising tide of ill health pushing millions out of work, reported its findings ahead of this month’s budgetEmployers have been told in a landmark government review that fixing Britain’s health-related worklessness crisis will require them to spend £6bn a year on support for their staff.In a major report before this month’s budget, Charlie Mayfield warned that businesses needed to play a more central role in tackling a rising tide of ill-health that is pushing millions of people out of work. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Babies born to black mothers 81% more likely to die in neonatal care, NHS study shows
clusters.neutral_headline: Babies born to black mothers 81% more likely to die in neonatal care, NHS study shows

items.title: Babies born to black mothers 81% more likely to die in neonatal care, NHS study shows
items.standfirst: Analysis of England and Wales units also finds 63% higher risk to babies whose mothers live in most deprived areasBabies born to black mothers in England and Wales and those from the most deprived areas are significantly more likely to die while in neonatal units, according to analysis revealing the “deeply concerning” figures.The study, led by academics at the University of Liverpool and published in The Lancet Child & Adolescent Health, examined data on more than 700,000 babies admitted to an NHS neonatal unit across England and Wales between 2012 and 2022. Continue reading...
items.content: Analysis of England and Wales units also finds 63% higher risk to babies whose mothers live in most deprived areasBabies born to black mothers in England and Wales and those from the most deprived areas are significantly more likely to die while in neonatal units, according to analysis revealing the “deeply concerning” figures.The study, led by academics at the University of Liverpool and published in The Lancet Child & Adolescent Health, examined data on more than 700,000 babies admitted to an NHS neonatal unit across England and Wales between 2012 and 2022. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Babies born to black mothers have higher mortality rates.
The study analyzed data from England and Wales.
Babies from deprived areas also face higher risks.
The study examined data from 2012 to 2022.
The study reveals concerning figures in neonatal care.

clusters.title: Soy, oat, almond, rice: which alternative milk is healthiest?
clusters.neutral_headline: Soy, oat, almond, rice: which alternative milk is healthiest?

items.title: Soy, oat, almond, rice: which alternative milk is healthiest?
items.standfirst: The best choice depends on your needs and preferences, say experts – here’s how to pick the one for your lifestyleThe dairy aisle might need a new name, given the diversity of products on offer. Dana Ellis Hunnes, a senior clinical dietitian at UCLA Health, says her local grocery store often stocks more non-dairy milk options than dairy ones. She’s tried various options, including a brief phase with coconut milk (“It was too creamy and too watery at the same time”). Now, she enjoys oat milk, which adds the right amount of creaminess to her coffee.The best choice depends on individual needs and preferences, says Hunnes. One person might want to add more protein to their diet, while another might be looking to increase their calcium intake. Flavor and mouthfeel are also important considerations. Continue reading...
items.content: The best choice depends on your needs and preferences, say experts – here’s how to pick the one for your lifestyleThe dairy aisle might need a new name, given the diversity of products on offer. Dana Ellis Hunnes, a senior clinical dietitian at UCLA Health, says her local grocery store often stocks more non-dairy milk options than dairy ones. She’s tried various options, including a brief phase with coconut milk (“It was too creamy and too watery at the same time”). Now, she enjoys oat milk, which adds the right amount of creaminess to her coffee.The best choice depends on individual needs and preferences, says Hunnes. One person might want to add more protein to their diet, while another might be looking to increase their calcium intake. Flavor and mouthfeel are also important considerations. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article discusses the healthiness of alternative milks.
The best choice depends on individual needs and preferences.
A dietitian suggests considering protein and calcium intake.
Flavor and mouthfeel are also important factors.
The article provides guidance on choosing milk alternatives.

items.title: A precious web of care still exists | Letters
items.standfirst: Keith Flett on the support his partner, Megan, received towards the end of her lifeMy long-term partner of 30 years, Megan Davies, died from lung cancer on 31 October.While I agree that there is much to be done to improve end-of-life care (Editorial, 29 October; Letters, 2 November), in Megan’s case, she was able to stay at home and enjoy many of the things she liked until a final two-day stay in hospital, where she also received good care. Continue reading...

The letter is in response to a previous editorial and other letters.
